item.title: What actually is Astronomy?
item.dc:creator: astrosalikriyaz
item.content:encoded:
What is Astronomy in simple words?

Astronomy is an aspect of science devoted to investigating the universe. It is a branch of natural science that analyzes celestial objects and events. It explains their origin and evolution using mathematics, physics, and chemistry.

Is it really just this?

NO! Astronomy isn't only the study of the celestial objects and limiting ourselves to them only. Astronomy isn't only about studying planets, moons, galaxies, etc. Rather, Astronomy can be said to be an envelop to everything we study(on a macro level, especially).

So, what actually is it?

As I said before, it is like an envelop which includes the study of everything in the universe. From Big Bang to Big Crunch, from evolution to deterioration, humans, life, psychology, philosophy, the enigmatic creation, it gives us the primary knowledge about everything and obviously the prime and the all of it about the outer space. It tells us how we were born. It tells us where we came from. It tells us where are we advancing towards. It tells us about our evolution. And it lets us guess our deterioration. It enlightens our knowledge and takes us from nothing to something to be called valuable, intelligent beings .

Astronomy is what leads a lost spirit beyond the horizons to the road of being acquainted with thyself.

AstroSalik Riyaz, Founder.

Is Astronomy same as Astrology?

The answer is obvious and the answer is, No! There is lot of difference between these two. The difference of the land and the sky. While Astronomy deals with the study of the universe for the betterment of our understanding and advancing in our life, Astrology says that it can predict future by studying the stars, planets and so which is absolutely in opposition of Science and Astronomy.

Let's take an example of myself;

I am a muslim boy who is obsessed with Astronomy. While studying it with great enthusiasm, I often get questions mentioning that Astronomy is Haram(prohibited) in Islam as it claims that it can tell us the future. But my response to them is that what I am studying is Astronomy, not Astrology. While Astrology, indeed, is prohibited in Islam, Astronomy on the other hand is a field of much encouragement. There have been great scientists from the Islamic background who have done the core research in this field. Not only this, There are approximately 1160 out of 6666 verses of Qur'an which are about Astronomy.

The other example is of Stephen Hawking as he has mentioned in his book "Brief Answers to Big Questions";

"I am an Astronomer, not an Astrologer"

Therefore, it is of no sense relating Astronomy to Astrology.

Just as the following meme denotes:

Astronomy encompasses various aspects, each offering unique insights into the cosmos. Let's delve into some of these aspects:

Observational Astronomy:

This area of study uses telescopes and other tools to see celestial objects and record data. Observational astronomers examine a wide range of light wavelengths, including gamma rays and radio waves, in order to develop a thorough picture of the universe. They study far-off galaxies, stars, planets, comets, asteroids, and other celestial bodies to learn about their characteristics.

Astrophysics:

Astrophysics is the study of astronomical objects using physics concepts. It tries to understand the fundamental processes that control the universe, such as stellar evolution, galaxies' behavior, the nature of dark matter and dark energy, and the genesis and fate of the universe itself. Astrophysicists examine these phenomena using theoretical models, computational simulations, and observational data.

Cosmology:

The area of astronomy known as cosmology explores the large-scale structure, genesis, and evolution of the cosmos. It aims to provide deep answers regarding the origins, growth, and ultimate destiny of the cosmos. Cosmologists build models and theories to explain the composition and development of the universe using observable data, such as the cosmic microwave background radiation, the distribution of galaxies, and the study of cosmic inflation.

Planetary Science:

The study of planets, moons, asteroids, and other solar system objects is the main goal of planetary science. In order to understand the genesis, evolution, and habitability of planets, scientists in this subject investigate their geological, atmospheric, and physical characteristics. They look into the makeup of atmospheres, explore planetary surfaces, evaluate data from space probes, and consider the possibility of extraterrestrial life.

Astrobiology:

Astrobiology investigates the potential for extraterrestrial life. This multidisciplinary field of study looks into the prerequisites needed for life to arise and persist in a variety of settings, including harsh ones. They investigate the possibility of habitable zones surrounding other stars, investigate Earth's extremophiles, and assess the possibility of extrasolar life on planets and moons.

These were a few facets of astronomy that help us study both our universe and ourselves.

Summary:

The science of astronomy helps us learn more about our universe and ourselves. Though it also helps us become more conscious of ourselves, its primary focus is the study of space. It tells us about evolution and retrogression in addition to discussing the universe.

Astronomy encompasses almost everything.

There lies a huge difference between Astronomy and Astrology. While the first one is truly scientific, the other one is obviously unscientific, respectively.

There are a lot of fields in the science of Astronomy which we can pursue to study ourselves.

We would love suggestions, questions, and feedback from your end.

Thankyou!

item.title: Astronomical Evolution
item.dc:creator: astrosalikriyaz
item.content:encoded:
We all are aware of the well-known theory, The Big Bang (However, it is most of the fact now due to some reasons which I will explain in the middle of this blog). But how did the big bang occur, what happened during it? What happened after it? How we are what, we are? How did it all began? And where are we heading towards.

Let's cover it all in our blogs!

Big Bang

Big Bang, the leading astronomical theory for the origin and evolution of the universe. The theory which explains our journey from nowhere, infinite dense and hot singularity, to the infinitely large universe. It describes the moment when all of the stuff it contains (matter, energy, space and time), packed into the very singularity, came out into existence of the perspective and drove the stuff to where it takes us now. However, it is necessary to know that our current understanding of the Big Bang is only limited to fractions of seconds after the Big Bang. The exact moment of the event still remains the topic of active research among the scientists.

According to the theory of Big Bang, the universe at the origin existed as singularity-the point of infinite density and temperature-approx. 13.8 billion years ago. At singularity, all of the fundamental forces we know (the electromagnetic force, the gravitational force, the weak force and the strong force) existed all as one, a grand unified force.

After the Big Bang, the universe started expanding and cooling down. The exponential expansion of the universe after fractions of the second of Big Bang is known as Cosmic Inflation. It is the hypothetical rapid expansion of the universe driven by a field known as inflaton field. This phase is known to have addressed some of the mysteries of the universe, which would be discussed below.

So, let's start with the subtheme of this blog, The Cosmic Inflation.

The Cosmic Inflation

What is Cosmic Inflation?

According to the theory of Cosmic Inflation, the universe expanded incredibly rapidly after the instant of the big bang.  It is termed as the exponential expansion of the universe. The very phase of accelerated expansion is believed to establish the initiates for the development of galaxies, stars, and all the structures we are able to observe now.

The Purpose of Inflation: Inflation was proposed to address some mysterious puzzles in Universe:

  • The Horizon problem: On the biggest scales, the universe appears remarkably isotropic (the same in all directions) and homogeneous. The primordial universe would not have had a sufficient amount of time for regions that were far apart to interact and establish temperature equilibrium. However, the cosmic microwave background radiation (CMB) reveals that the celestial temperature is remarkably constant. The observed uniformity can be explained by cosmic inflation, permitting different locations to have been in contact prior to the fast expansion.
  • The Flatness Problem: The geometry of the cosmos appears to be exceptionally close to being flat, according to observations. However, the amount of the energy and matter that makes up the universe affects how space is curved. If the cosmos had not been disproportionately flat at the beginning, it would have gradually deviated from flatness. The cosmos is flattened by inflation, which is consistent with the almost flat geometry we currently experience.
  • The Large-Scale Structure Problem: Without cosmic inflation, it is difficult to explain the large-scale structure of the universe, which is characterised by the clumping of galaxies and galaxy clusters into patterns mimicking cosmic webs. The early universe's imperfections were smoothed out by inflation's fast expansion, which also laid the groundwork for subsequent galaxy and cluster formation.

Key aspects of Cosmic Inflation:

  • Inflaton Field: The universe's energy was regulated by an imagined scalar field termed as the inflaton during inflation. This field's unique energy conditions triggered the exponential expansion of the cosmos.
  • Exponential Expansion: The universe rapidly expanded in size as a consequence of the energy of the inflaton, expanding at an exponential pace. Due to the fact that this expansion entailed the expansion of space itself rather than space-moving objects, it did not deviate from the laws of special relativity while occurring much faster than the speed of light.
  • End of Inflation: The inflaton field eventually underwent a phase change, and inflation subsided. The inflaton field's energy was released, causing particles to be synthesised and starting the universe's evolution's characteristic Big Bang phase.

Why is Big Bang a fact now?
The following are some of the main arguments in favour of the Big Bang theory's high credibility and solid foundation:
Cosmic Microwave Background Radiation:
The discovery of the existence of cosmic microwave background (CMB) radiation is one of the most important pieces of evidence for the Big Bang. The universe is filled with this weak radiation, which is essentially the afterglow of the hot, dense early universe. The Big Bang theory anticipated the CMB, and its discovery by Arno Penzias and Robert Wilson in 1965 gave confirmational support.
Abundance of Light ElementsThe amount of light elements like hydrogen and helium in the universe is precisely predicted by the Big Bang theory. These elements were produced in the ratios we see today as a result of nucleosynthesis, which took place during the early universe's intensely hot and dense expansion.

Large-Scale Structure of the Universe:
Galaxy clusters and cosmic filaments are illustrations of the large-scale structure of the universe, and their observations are in line with the Big Bang theory's and space-time's expansion's predictions.
Hubble's Law:
Galaxies are shifting apart from one another, which is in accordance with Edwin Hubble's discoveries from the 1920s that the universe is expanding. This discovery confirms the Big Bang theory's hypothesis that the universe emerged amid a hot, dense state.
Predictions and Consistency:
The acceptability of the Big Bang theory is further strengthened by the fact that many of its predictions came true. Furthermore, it continues to stand in agreement with a variety of experimental discoveries and astronomical observations.

Post-Inflation Universe:

The hot Big Bang phase began when the universe was filled with energy and particles post inflation. The separation of matter and radiation occurred as particles came together to form atoms as the cosmos continued to expand and cool. This liberated up space for light to travel. The cosmic microwave background radiation, which we can measure now, is a byproduct of this decoupling.

Observational Support:

Although cosmic inflation is a captivating scientific theory, more empirical data is required to completely validate it. The exact temperature measurements of the cosmic microwave background, which agree with the predictions of inflationary models, are one of the most important pieces of evidence for inflation. Furthermore, observations of the universe's large-scale structures are in conformity with our expectations of the initial circumstances brought about by inflation.

To sum up, cosmic inflation is a strong astronomical idea that offers a compelling justification for some of the universe's most mysterious characteristics. It pushes the limits of our knowledge of the cosmos by providing insights into the universe's early history and aiding in our comprehension of its current large-scale structure. Our knowledge of cosmic inflation and its role in determining the history of the universe continues to be enhanced by ongoing observations and experiments.

To be Continued...

This was all for this blog. In our next blogs, we will discuss other matters like Formation of galaxies etc. and gradually we will cover all of the questions mentioned earlier and I also encourage you to post some other questions you are curious about in the comment section related to it and I'll try my best to include those questions too. Thanks for reading this blog to the end. Don't forget to subscribe. Stay blessed!

item.title: Astronomical Evolution II - The Formation of Galaxies
item.dc:creator: astrosalikriyaz
item.content:encoded:
In our recent blog, we started with the Big Bang and continued with cosmic inflation. We studied the purpose of inflation, key aspects of inflation, post-inflation universe. We also backed the theory with observational support and also provided the theory of big bang, a factual back. And after all of this, we are ready to move on to the next step and resume our journey of "Astronomical Evolution" with our next subtheme, "The Formation of Galaxies."

How are galaxies formed? What role does instability perform? Why is dark matter necessary for the formation of galaxies? Let's find out!

The Formation of Galaxies

One of the most intriguing phenomena in the history of the cosmos is the creation of galaxies. Galaxies are enormous systems that are held together by gravity and are made up of stars, gas, dust, and dark matter. They range in size and shape from tiny dwarf galaxies to enormous elliptical and spiral galaxies, each of which contains billions to trillions of stars. It takes billions of years and a number of important conditions for galaxies to develop, and this process is dynamic and complex;

Cosmic inflation and initial density fluctuations:

A fraction of a second after the Big Bang, the early cosmos is thought to have undergone cosmic inflation, a fast exponential expansion. Small changes in the density of matter and energy occurred during inflation as a result of quantum oscillations in the energy field that causes inflation. The subsequent development of galaxies and other cosmic structures was sparked by these minute variations. As the inflationary phase drew to a close, the hot Big Bang phase of the universe's development began, converting the energy held in the inflaton field into particles and radiation. Over time, matter began to cluster together due to the gravitational pull of the initial density fluctuations, eventually giving rise to the vast structures that we see in the universe today. It was proposed to unravel some of the most deep mysteries of the creation and development of the cosmos. Alan Guth, Andrei Linde, and other physicists initially proposed the concept in the early 1980s.

Gravitational Instability:

The cosmos started to expand and cool after inflation. Over time, gravity drew additional significance to areas with somewhat higher concentrations of matter. Gravitational instabilities enhanced the variations in density as matter continued to cluster together.

Gravitational instability is a phenomenon whereby a system with gravity acting on itself, a self-gravitating system, becomes unstable and collapses under its own gravity. This process is considered to be the fundamental mechanism for the formation of celestial bodies such as stars (and also the cause of their demise) as well as systems like galaxies.

For a self-gravitating system to become unstable, there are two main factors: mass and angular momentum. The mass of the system determines the strength of its gravitational field, while the angular momentum determines how easily the system can rotate. The gravitational collapse is directly proportional to the mass of the system and is inversely proportional to the angular momentum. In other words, if the system has a very low mass, the gravitational force cannot overcome the forces of thermal energy and pressure, thus preventing the system from collapsing. Similarly, if the angular momentum of the system is too high to rotate fast enough, it will prevent the collapse of the system.

Once the system becomes unstable, it starts to collapse. The system itself gets more and more compressed. Pressure and temperature also increases. Eventually, the conditions become favorable for nuclear fusion to occur, leading to the formation of the galaxy.

Gravitational process is a foundational process for the formation of not only galaxies but also stars, planets, moons, and even yourself in the long run. It is also responsible for the distribution of different objects such as stars and planets within the galaxy.

Dark Matter:

Dark matter, a mysterious substance unknown to our understanding, comprises the majority of the universe, accounting for approximately 85% of its matter. While we cannot observe this invisible dark matter directly, we can detect its presence through its effects on visible matter. This enigmatic matter plays a crucial role in the formation of galaxies.

Post-inflation, the universe was filled with density fluctuations of both baryonic (ordinary) and dark matter. As the universe expanded, regions with a higher concentration of dark matter began to attract and accumulate more dark matter. As dark matter clumped to form Dark Matter Halos, galaxies were provided with gravitational wells within which the galaxies would later accumulate. It also attracted baryonic matter more and more, and due to the high concentration of baryonic matter, the matter collapsed under the gravitational force, paving the way for the occurrence of nuclear fusion and hence, the formation of stars and galaxies.

With the formation of the galaxies, the accretion of dark matter from the surrounding regions shaped the galaxies into their current form. The Dark Matter Halos accumulated on the outlines of the galaxy, preventing the galaxies from flying apart.

The distribution of dark matter in the galaxy is very uneven. It is highly concentrated towards the center, while much less towards the outskirts of the galaxy. It has been theorized, through observations, that the dark matter halos that surround the galaxy are much larger than the visible galaxy itself! The dark matter halo of the Milky Way Galaxy is thought to be about the radius of 100,000 light years, while the total size of the visible Milky Way is about 100,000 light years in diameter.

Overall, the mysterious dark matter is a pivotal matter for the formation and well working of galaxies.

A little more to it in the next blog.

Keeping in mind that I don't have to exhaust you with long bolgs, let's put a pause to this subtheme and continue the exploration of the formation of galaxies in the next episode. Tillâ€‚then, let me bid you a goodbye. Stay happy, stay contended, stay blessed.

Thank you.

item.title: Astronomical Evolution III - How are galaxies formed, continued.
item.dc:creator: astrosalikriyaz
item.content:encoded:
In the previous episode of this series, we studied some aspects of the formation of galaxy. In this episode we will continue the very subtheme, "The Formation of Galaxies." If you haven't yet been through the previous blog, then have a look at that before continuing.

https://zoonigia.wordpress.com/2024/01/04/astronomical-evolution-ii/â€‚

Now, ignite your curiosity and let's continue our cosmic odessey.

Why Star Formation is necessary?

The formation of stars is complex and is a similar process to that of the formation of galaxies, but on a much smaller scale. Stars form from gigantic interstellar clouds of gas and dust that are spread throughout the galaxy, constituting about 1% of the galaxy's mass. Stars are the main source of energy (light and heat) for the galaxy. Without stars, galaxies would be different entities, and they play a crucial role in the genesis and progression of galaxies. Stars are also responsible for the formation of planets.

Let's study how they are formed;

The gas and dust present in the interstellar coulds(molecular) is very cold, having temperature about 10-20 Kelvin. Hence, they are not moving much fast and and attracted to one another with ease giving rise to the formation of clumps of gas and dust, called the prestellar cores, having mass upto 100 solar masses.

Since, prestellar cores keep up to collapse under its own gravitational force, they become more and more denser and hotter. The density can extend to 100 million times the density as on Earth and the temperature can reach up to 100,000 kelvin. At such a stage, the core is known as protostar.

The protostar persists collapsing onto itself, increasing pressure and temperature to such an extent that the conditions become favourable for the occurence of nuclear fusion, a process where hydrogen in converted into helium atom, releasing enormous energy. This process is the cause of the star to shine(leave a comment if you want to know in detail about nuclear fusion).

The protostar is finally converted to a star, which would shine for billions of years, giving rise to planetary system, and increasing the probability of generating life on atleast one of its planets. Eventually, there comes a time when it runs out of its nuclear fuel and it, too, collapses under its gravity.

A few additional points to remeber;

The process of the formation of stars can take millions of years.

The mass of star is inversely proportional to its's life span, ie,. if the star is massive, it will have a shorter lifespan accordingly.

The formation of stars is a captivating process, making a galaxy worth evolving.

How Feedback mechanism effects the process?

Galaxies are dynamic systems with many different types of feedback processes at work. For instance, the interstellar medium is replenished with energy and matter by supernova explosions from large stars and active galactic nuclei from supermassive black holes. The galaxy's development is controlled by this feedback, which also has the potential to cause gas outflows and which can result from a number of things, including as the emergence of stars, the presence of black holes, and interactions between galaxies, and they can be either positive or negative.

Galaxies expand as a result of positive feedback mechanisms, which increase this growth. They may result from star formation, which heats up a galaxy's gas and prevents it from cooling and producing new stars. More massive stars may eventually emerge as a result, which might generate even more heat and energy.

Negative feedback mechanism are generally from black holes which expell jets of hot gas and prevents the formation of stars, eventually resulting in the suppression of the growth of galaxy.

Morphology and evolution of Galaxies:

Galaxy Morphology, the branch of Astronomy, concerned with the structure of galaxies, is the study, discussing their physical appearences.

Galaxies demonstrate variety of morphologies such as, spiral, lenticular, elliptical, and irregular, which depend on their history, their interactions with other galaxies and the phenomenon happening inside.

We can classify galaxies using the system of galaxy classification developed by Sir Edwin Hubble in the 1020's called The Hubble Sequence. The Hubble sequence divides the galaxies into four major types of galaxies mentioned above.

We can aslo classify the galaxies by other means based on their morphology which includes, asymmetry index, concentration index, and clumpiness index. These indices can be used to determine the shape and structure of galaxies, and can also be used to track their evolution over the long span of time.

The study of Galaxy Evolution examines how galaxies evolve throughout time. The origin, development, and ultimate destiny of galaxies are studied in this area of astronomy.

The gravitational interactions between galaxies, the accretion of gas and dust, and the birth and development of stars are all believed to play a vital role in the evolution of galaxies.

Large clouds of gas and dust are theorised to collapse and create galaxies. The clouds form a disk-shaped galaxy when they burst. After that, as the disk-shaped galaxy gathers gas and dust, stars emerge. The galaxy's stars then undergo evolution and death, expelling copious gas and dust.

Galaxies undergo a complicated process of evolution that is yet not completely understood. But as scientists continue to understand more about galaxy development, we are gradually learning the mysteries of how galaxies evolve through time.

To be continued...

This is all for today's blog. Gaining much knowledge about our universe is truly captivating. I hope we can continue this journey together, and when we conclude this series, we will have benefited greatly. I sincerely express my gratitude to all who have stayed with us till now. Thank you very much. May you be blessed.

It would mean a lot if you subscribe and share this site with your loved ones to encourage me and acknowledge them.

Thank you.

item.title: The history of the founder's nickname, "Astro"
item.dc:creator: astrosalikriyaz
item.content:encoded:
I was studying in class IX when my dearest friend, Mr. Muntazir Zarger, who is also my relative, advised me to create a page on Instagram where I could share some knowledge with others. Initially, I was apprehensive because my brother had previously forbidden me from using Instagram, claiming it wasn't a beneficial platform. However, after pondering over Muntazir's suggestion, I decided to take the leap and create the page.

The first challenge I faced was thinking of an appropriate name for my page. As an enthusiast of space and astronomy, I had noticed that many astronauts had the prefix "Astro" before their names. Inspired by this, I settled on the name "astrosalikriyaz" for my Instagram page.

Creating the page opened up a whole new world for me. I connected with like-minded individuals, fellow knowledge seekers, and individuals who were passionate about science and space exploration. It was a virtual community where I could share interesting facts, educational content, and engage in thought-provoking discussions.

As I immersed myself in this new venture, I found myself distancing from the physical world around me. I became engrossed in the process of curating content and interacting with my followers. People would rarely get the chance to talk to me directly, even through virtual means. Only a selected few had the privilege of engaging in virtual conversations with me. My focus was solely on delivering high-quality content to my followers and expanding my reach.

However, life had a way of surprising me. One day, my brother happened to stumble upon my Instagram page during a visit to Muntazir's home. When I heard about it, I felt a mix of fear and anxiety. I anticipated a negative reaction from my brother, as he had previously prohibited me from using Instagram. As the days passed, I anxiously awaited his return home, dreading the confrontation that awaited me.

Finally, the day of his return arrived, and I went to pick him up. With each step towards him, my worry intensified. However, to my astonishment, there was no negative reaction on his face. I couldn't decipher his thoughts, and I assumed he would reprimand me once we reached home. But, to my relief, no such response came.

Eventually, the conversation about my Instagram page began, and I was once again pleasantly surprised by the reaction I received. Not only did he acknowledge the existence of my page, he expressed genuine enthusiasm and encouragement. It was a moment that truly touched my heart.

His words of support resonated deeply within me, igniting a renewed sense of passion and purpose in pursuing my creative endeavors. With his unwavering belief in me, I felt empowered to further explore and refine my artistic expression.

But his involvement didn't stop at mere words of encouragement. No, he went above and beyond to actively assist me in my endeavors. He became instrumental in the growth and visibility of my Instagram page, using his network and influence to attract new followers and create a sense of community around my work.

item.title: Astronomical Evolution IV - The Cosmic Dark Age
item.dc:creator: astrosalikriyaz
item.content:encoded:
In our recent blog of this series, we learned about the formation of galaxies with different references such as dark matter, morphology, gravitation, etc. Today, we will peer into a concept that acts as an intermediary between the universe at the time when everything was starting up and the universe today, which is known to us as the modern era of the universe. So, let's get started and dive in.

Overview of the cosmic dark age

About 380,000 years after the Big Bang, to about one billion years, the universe was filled with hydrogen as a foggy substance which interrupted the photons ability to travel freely, hence making the universe translucent. These hydrogen atoms weren't yet ionized, and therefore, they absorbed the energy of the photons. This period is known as the cosmic dark age, which came to an end when the powerful ultraviolet light emitted from stars after the formation of galaxies and stars ionized the hydrogen atoms in the universe and marked the beginning of the modern era of the universe. Now, let's peer into it.

Introduction to the primordial/ancient Universe:

In the early times, after the process of recombination, began a phase known as the cosmic dark age, near about 380,000 years after the Big Bang. The universe was extremely hot before recombination and consisted of radiation and plasma of charged particles, i.e., electrons and protons. The particles of light, known as photons, were scattered by this plasma and, as a result, were prevented from traveling freely.

What is Recombination

Recombination was the primary step in the era of the cosmic dark age. It was the phenomenon of the formation of neutral hydrogen atoms from protons and electrons when the temperature went down to about 3000 Kelvin or approx. 2727 degrees Celsius. The result was that there was no hindrance to the travel of photons, and therefore, the universe became transparent. It was the time when photons were released freely in the vastness of the universe, and we get to observe it today as the Cosmic Microwave Background radiation, providing us a glimpse of the universe's state at that very time.

Decoupling

Post recombination, there was a fog of hydrogen gas all around, which was very cold and transparent to the particles of light known as photons. At around 370,000 years, during the period of recombination, photons were emitted, and they traveled so far that they became redshifted, causing their wavelengths to increase and making them unable to interact further with hydrogen atoms. This process is known as decoupling.

Release of CMB

The decoupled photons from the matter during recombination are the very photons we witness today as cosmic microwave background radiation (CMB). We can say that it's a faint glow of the primordial universe in the form of microwave radiation, spreading throughout the universe, which we can have a look at. The CMB, the mighty proof of the Big Bang, provides us with important insights into the primordial universe and its evolution. It helps us understand our universe with great might.

Formation of stars and galaxies

In the aftermath of decoupling, we had an empty, dark universe. Nonetheless, it was filled with gas and dust. According to one of the major theories about the formation of stars and galaxies, there existed dense regions that were hundreds of times smaller than the smallest galaxies known to exist today, called minihalos. These regions collapsed under their own gravity, resulting in the formation of the first stars and galaxies.

The other theory suggests that galaxies and stars could have formed around the Black holes, as their immense density could have helped the matter around them collapse and turn into these forms.

The Epoch of Reionization

The epoch of reionization is a complex process. It was a time of great happenings in the universe. During this period, which was from 400 million years to 1 billion years post-Big Bang, the neutral hydrogen fog filled the universe, making it translucent to light and resisting the free movement of photons. The unionized hydrogen atom absorbed the energy of the photon and prohibited its motion across the universe. But then, after the formation of stars and galaxies, the ultraviolet light emitted from the stars ionized the hydrogen gas. This process is known as reionization, and it commenced the beginning of the modern era universe. During this time, there happened to form the first stars and galaxies, and even the first Black Holes.

However, this topic is still poorly understood relative to the other concepts and is still an area of research among the scientists. It's because of the presence of hydrogen as fog that we are unable to have a clear look into the past. In spite of this, scientists are using new techniques to study about this very event.

Some of the techniques used by the Astronomers are given below;

The Study of Cosmic Microwave Background:

The CMB is a faint but very uniform afterglow of the Cosmos. However, due to some small fluctuations in its uniformity, we are able to study the epoch of reionization by measuring the amount of neutral hydrogen gas present in the universe at the time of the event.

The Study of Quasars:

Quasars, which emerged from the darkest ever existing bodies known as black holes (here, super massive black holes), are the brightest in the cosmos. And from these quasars gets emitted the ultraviolet radiation, reacting with the neutral hydrogen atom to ionize it and thus creating a shadow in the quasar's light, which in turn helps the astronomers research about the very period of the epoch of reionization with more depth by giving us a more accurate approximation about the quantity of the neutral hydrogen atom present at that time.

The study of 21cm emission:

The 21-centimeter-wavelength radiation emitted from the neutral hydrogen atom is faint and thus difficult to observe, but it is a pivotal approach towards monitoring the epoch of reionization as the radiation of this wavelength can be used to calculate the amount of the neutral hydrogen atom present at the very time of the event. In this regard, astronomers are taking steps towards developing new ways of studying this wavelength so as to take a deeper look into the event.

As astronomers advance in their techniques to study the epoch of reionization, we have a greater propensity to learn about this essential phase in the evolution of the universe.

The End of the Cosmic Dark Age

After some 1 billion years since the Big Bang, most of the hydrogen atoms were no longer neutral; rather, they had been ionized. Thus, the cosmos was not dark any more; it was filled with light. It was advancing towards sustaining mysteries, sustaining dark secrets, sustaining life, and stabilizing the laws on a major scale. The formation of large-scale structures as the framework of the upcoming galaxies and structures, the release of enormous energy from gigantic existing stars and galaxies, speeding up the process of further ionization, and a cosmos teeming with vibrant activities and brimming with celestial wonders. Then, it was the time when everything destined was to come into the existence. The end of the Cosmic Dark Age and the initialization of the modern-era Universe!

To be continued...

That was all about this stunning period of the universe. As you immerse yourself in the captivating world of 'Astronomical Evolution,' I hope you find yourself enriched with boundless knowledge and an insatiable curiosity for the mysteries of the universe. Once again, I would like to express my gratitude to all of you who are connected to the blogs and are helping me grow. If you are a new visitor, thanks for taking a look. I hope you, too, will connect with us. Let your spirit soar among the stars as we explore the infinite depths of the universe, and may your passion for knowledge blaze brighter than the brightest of supernovas.

Thank you.

item.title: Astronomical Evolution V - How do stars evolve? Stellar Evolution I
item.dc:creator: astrosalikriyaz
item.content:encoded:
Stellar evolution, a fascinating and complex process in the universe, is responsible for the changes in the course of life of stars we see and do not see during their lifetime. The mass composition of stars, ranging from less massive to supermassive, determines the ultimate fate of their course post-nova. While our own true star, the Sun, has a lifetime of about 10billion years in this state, of which it has already blessed us with its 4.5billion years, a star, say 10 times more massive than it, would have a lifetime of about 10million years only, i.e., 0.1% the life of Sun. But what after the years of its lifetime as a star? What would happen, how would it be, and how would all of this take place? How is the sun's mass a determinant of its ultimate fate? Letâ€™s delve into it to decode it and embark on uncovering the answers to what, why, and how in this new sub-series, Stellar Evolution.

A star, just like our beloved Sun, spends most of its lifetime in a state called the Main sequence phase of the star, the very phase our Sun is going through at the moment. During this phase, the star uses its nuclear fuel against its gravitational force to avoid collapsing on itself. The nuclear fuel is hydrogen, which fuses into helium. But as I promised the answer to how, letâ€™s know the how behind it.

Nuclear Fusion

In the 19th century, some scientists, such as Kelvin and Helmholtz, believed that the mysterious sun could be explained entirely by gravity. As we have already discussed in our recent blogs, a huge mass of gas and dust collapsed under gravity and gave rise to the formation of the sun, releasing a lot of energy. While this might explain why the sun began to be terribly hot, it doesnâ€™t explain why it has been hot for so long. Therefore, it remained a mystery until a clear model of the atom emerged and started unraveling the mysteries behind the sun and other stars. An atom has a tiny nucleus at the center composed of protons and neutrons.

The earlier calculations provided us with the following details:

The mass of the sun is 2 âœ• 10^30 kg which implies that it has 10^57 atoms.
Therefore, the Sun produces about 3.84 âœ• 10^24 watts.

But this cycle would only last for about 20,000 years.

And this isnâ€™t the mechanism of the Sun, of course.

So how does the sun produce this incredible energy since 4.5 billion years?

Sir Albert Einstein gave us the equation E = mc^2. This equation states that a bit of mass can be turned into a lot of energy as itâ€™s multiplied by the incredible speed of light. But the sun cannot convert all of its mass into energy. If it does so, then its total energy would be equal to 1.8âœ•10^47j and the energy it would release would be equal to 3.8âœ•10^26joules/sec. This mechanism implies that the Sun would burn for 15 trillion years.

But the sun actually converts only 0.7% of its mass into energy.

Letâ€™s now get into the mechanism of how the sun releases so much energy. Letâ€™s study nuclear fusion.

Before moving ahead, let me make you aware of some facts related to nuclear energy.

Nuclear reactions, unlike chemical reactions that involve electrons, are caused by the involvement of the nucleons, protons and neutrons.

Nuclear reactions are 5,000,000 times more powerful than chemical reactions.

Just a pound of the hydrogen 2 isotope, known as deuterium, is enough to power 10,000 homes per year.

These were some basic insights into nuclear reactions.

Hans Bethe was born in the year 1906 and died in the year I was born, i.e., 2005. He made major contributions in the fields of quantum electrodynamics, astrophysics, nuclear physics, and solid-state physics and was also the 1967 winner of the Nobble Prize in physics for his theory of stellar nucleosynthesis. He worked to explain the process going on inside the sun.

  • The Sun is mostly made up of Hydrogen-1, i.e., protium, which is just a proton.
  • The Sun is very hot and dense, so these protons collide.
  • But this doesnâ€™t cause the nuclear reaction because of the absence of neutrons.
  • Usually, when protons collide, they fly apart. But, very rarely, something else happens: beta decay.

Coulomb's force prohibits a proton from meeting another proton. This prevents atoms from fusing spontaneously. Protons have a positive charge, which repels the other positive charge, the proton. The electromagnetic force causes them to repel and never meet. The closer they get, the more repulsion they observe. But at a very close distance, about the width of a proton, the strong force takes over the electromagnetic force. It becomes 100 times more powerful than the electromagnetic force. But for that, protons have to overcome this Coulomb barrier. Once they get over it and get much closer to each other, the strong force takes over and plays its role. But letâ€™s ask another â€œhowâ€.

How does this happen? (The ultimate aim is to take helium atom from 4 hydrogen atoms)

  • The extreme temperature, about 15,000,000 degrees, rips atoms into their components.
  • The extreme pressure forces these components to be in close proximity to each other.

This is enough for fusion, but the Sun has a trick.

Keeping the blog concise, the trick will be discussed in the next blog. Till then, feed your passion and let's together enjoy our obsession â€” The Space Science. Thank You for joining us.

item.title: Introduction To Black Holes
item.dc:creator: hiuazyeralygmailcom
item.content:encoded:
Have you ever heard about black holes? Do you want to know more and dive a little deeper? Let's go.

The interesting domain of astrophysics dives into the study of black holes, which first got significant attention in 1967 owing to American physicist John Wheeler. Prior to his influence, astronomers often referred to these celestial wonders as "Totally Gravitationally Collapsed Objects." Supermassive black holes, which exist in the centers of huge galaxies, have masses that are millions or billions of times larger than our Sun. These enigmatic phenomena have gravitational forces so strong that even light succumbs to their attraction, forcing objects to move faster than the speed of light to escapeâ€”an idea that challenges the principles of Albert Einstein's special theory of relativity, published in 1905.

Stephen Hawking and Roger Penrose further illuminated the mysteries of black holes, demonstrating that time itself concludes within these cosmic entities. The singularity at the heart of a black hole, a point in space-time where curvature becomes infinite, imprisons objects, rendering escape impossible. The general theory of relativity, which was developed by Albert Einstein in 1916, shows how mass bends the elastic, invisible fabric of space-time and explains gravity as a result.

Even though gravitational waves are emitted by all objects during space-time curvature, it can be difficult to identify them in a simple moving object. On the other hand, gravitational wave emission frequencies offer a possible way to find black holes. By detecting mergers, items near black holes can be observed, which advances our knowledge of these cosmic occurrences.

Why are Black Holes black?

This color results from their strong gravitational attraction, which is caused by their strong gravitational fields. Black holes don't have surfaces, but they do have a unique boundary called an event horizon. The event horizon of the most basic black hole is a sphere with a radius known as the Schwarzschild radius (R=2GM/c^2).

What's accretion disk and how's it formed?

An accretion disk, a spinning disk of matter, isÂ formed when a star approaches a black hole. When a portion of the star's radiation interacts with the disk close to the event horizon, it releases X-rays. Once an item crosses the Schwarzschild radius, escape from the black hole's gravity becomes impossible.

What is an Ergosphere?

The ergosphere, also known as Kerr black holes,Â a third area where a black hole affects nearby space, is introduced by rotating black holes.A swirling black hole's ergosphere is the area outside its event horizon where spacetime is pulled into its interior by its revolution. The rotation of the black hole causes space itself to rotate within this region. Because of this, an object inside the ergosphere is forced to rotate in the direction of the black hole's rotation and cannot stay motionless in relation to observers outside of it.

Conclusion

Astrophysicists have recently discovered a large number of black holes. Going forward, the idea of using black holesâ€”especially small onesâ€”as energy reservoirs is still an intriguing one.

In conclusion, many people are curious about the study of black holes, which was made popular by the film Interstellar. In order to comprehend these cosmic occurrences, it is necessary to decipher the complexities of space-time curvature, gravity, and the enormous effects that black holes have on their surroundings.

Quantum tunneling:

This is a phenomenon where a particle, say an atom, has the capability to teleport to the other side of a barrier. The wavefunction propagates through the potential barrier by disappearing on one side and reappearing on the other. It is possible due to the uncertainty principle in quantum mechanics. The Sun uses this trick to increase the efficiency of nuclear reactions.

This  says: uncertainty in energy times Uncertainty in time equals a constant.

If energy is borrowed and given back in such a short period of time that it cannot be measured, it is permitted. It is such that the universe didnâ€™t record it. This is the nature of quantum mechanics.

Î”E * Î”t < h / 4Ï€

This implies that the protons can borrow energy for a very short period of time, such that it tunnels through the Coulombâ€™s barrier as if it weren't there. Therefore, instead of going over the ridge, it goes straight through the barrier and travels to the other side. This usually happens in quantum mechanics when there is a lower energy state on the other side.

This phenomenon significantly enhances the sustainability of fusion, in the sun.

Now, after the protons have collided, they usually fly apart. But as mentioned earlier, rarely something different would happenâ€”beta decay. Beta decay causes protons and neutrons to switch identities.

If it were the case of a neutron, it would easily turn into a proton by losing some of its mass, as it is heavier than the proton. But here, the proton has to turn into a neutron, and thus it will undergo 'beta + decayâ€™, but it cannot do it alone; unlike neutrons, it has to be with others.

Letâ€™s study beta decay.

A proton collides with another proton, and one of the two protons changes into a neutron.

Inside a proton, there are three quarks: two up quarks have charge +2\3 and one down quark has charge -1\3. On adding up these charges, we get the charge of the proton to be +1, which we know is the relative charge of the proton. In a neutron, we have one up quark and two down quarks, and when we add up their charges, we get the charge of the neutron to be 0. Now, letâ€™s take a look at the inside of a proton. One of the up quarks inside the proton releases the w-boson. It is a fundamental particle with a charge of -1. This w-boson travels to the quark of another proton and changes the up quark into a down quark. Thus, the other proton now has two down quarks and one up quark, which is the characteristic of a neutron. Therefore, the proton has turned into a neutron. In this process, the proton that has turned into a neutron releases a positron (an antiparticle of an electron) and a neutrino. This neutrino has a very high speed, near that of light. It travels out of the sun and may travel through your body without informing you. On average, trillions of neutrinos pass through our body every second. The positron released may interact with its antiparticle, known as the electron, and annihilate while releasing tons of energy. Their interaction creates a gamma ray, which is the most energetic form of photon.

This is the process of the formation of neutron from a proton and this is the first step in the process of transformation of Hydrogen to helium, which is the main objective of nuclear fusion in Sun.

Now, when we have a pair of nucleons where one is a proton and the other is a neutron, or, in simple terms, the nucleus of the hydrogen-2 isotope or Deuterium, this pair finds another proton and combines it with itself. thus forming the nucleus of the Helium-3 isotope, which has two protons and one neutron.

After this, it is in search of another Helium-3 isotope, and when it finds it, it combines with it, forming the isotope of Beryllium (Be-6) with 4 protons and 2 neutrons. This isotope of Beryllium is unstable, and it loses two of its protons, leaving us with two protons and two neutrons, the nucleus of Helium. But remember, we have electrons to deal with. Here, we have two protons and two neutrons. But these two neutrons were actually protons before, i.e., they were hydrogen atoms. Thus, we should have four electrons according to this in the orbits of Helium, but Helium has only two electrons. If you remember, we have earlier mentioned positrons, and we also mentioned that these positrons react with electrons to annihilate and generate gamma rays. But where do those electrons come from? Those electrons are the very electrons we are talking about. At that moment, they interacted with these electrons and released gamma rays, which in turn added to the energy of the sun. Thus, we only have the two required electrons and thus a perfect Helium.

Not only does it produce energy during the first step, but it releases energy at every step.

So, initially, we had four Hydrogen atoms, which transformed to make one Helium atom.

Talking about the time each step takes, the first step, where we finally have the pair comprising one proton and one neutron, takes about 1 billion years.

The second step, where it adds another proton, takes about 4 seconds.

And the final step takes about 400 years, where it has to find another Helium-3 isotope and form the beryllium isotope into a helium-4 isotope, or simply a standard Helium atom.

Now you know how the energy is generated. But where does this energy come from?

item.dc:creator: astrosalikriyaz
item.content:encoded:
The mass of one hydrogen atom is 1.008, and the mass of one Helium atom is 4.0026.

We know that the Helium atom originated from four hydrogen atoms.

So mathematically,

4âœ•Hydrogen = 4âœ•1.008 = 4.032.

But the net mass of Helium is 4.0026.

The difference equals 0.0294, or in percentage, 0.7%.

I hope you remember when I earlier mentioned that the Sun only converts 0.7% of its mass to energy. This tiny difference in mass is responsible for almost all of the energy that the sun generates. And this is the source that keeps the sun from collapsing.

But, being a Quantum physics enthusiast, Letâ€™s go deeper.

You are now aware of the fact that energy comes from the reduction of mass. But where does this come from?

Letâ€™s unravel it in a quantum way.

If we talk in terms of energy units, the mass of a proton will be 938.3 MeV, while the mass of a neutron will be 939.6 MeV. We know Helium has two protons and two neutrons. Therefore,

2âœ•proton = 2 âœ• 938.3 = 1876.6Mev, and

2âœ•neutron = 2 âœ• 939.6 = 1879.2Mev

When we add them up, we get the total mass of 3755.8 MeV.  But the actual mass of Helium is 3728.4 MeV. The difference between the two comes out to be 27.4 Mev, or 0.7%

But what actually happened? How does Helium have lower energy units than the four individual nucleons?

Actually, it turns out that the four nucleons of Helium are more stable when they are together than when they are separated. This higher stability is the reason behind the difference in energy units. Helium has four nucleons, which implies that it has more binding energy than hydrogen, which has only one nucleon. Binding energy is the energy required to pull the nucleons apart. Hydrogen has zero binding energy as there isnâ€™t any other nucleon to pull the proton from.

Now, as a curious quantum physics enthusiast, letâ€™s dive in deeper.

Letâ€™s get to the crux of the source of energy.

If we now take quarks into account, we get to know that only 1% of the total mass comes from the Higgs field. If we look into the proton,

The mass of two up quarks plus the mass of one down quark sums up to 9.1 MeV. But the mass of a proton, as mentioned earlier, equals 938.3 MeV. This equation implies that quarks add up to only 1% of the total mass.

So, where does the rest of the energy come from?

It comes from one of the four fundamental forces of the universe, the strong force. This force is the glue that keeps the quarks bound to the nucleus.

Gluon (a fundamental particle) exchange results in strong force interactions inside nucleons. Inside the nucleons, thereâ€™s a plasma called the quark-gluon plasma, which consists of quark-gluon interactions. This plasma is the result of the combination of quarks and gluons. They are moving at enormous speeds, and thus, a lot of energy is bound up not only in their movements but also in the energy that binds the plasma together.

Therefore, we reach the conclusion that kinetic energy and binding energy make up about 98% of the mass. This is where the rest of the mass comes from.

Now, hereâ€™s the conclusion:

When multiple nucleons are together, there is less energy requirement than there would be when the nucleon was alone. This is because the quarks and gluons are now bound to the nucleons. They can easily move in and out of the nucleons as they are easily exchanged within the nucleons or with neighboring nucleons. They donâ€™t need any extra energy in this process. The exchange of quarks is executed by Mesons. Mesons are quark-antiquark pairs that get formed in the process. These Mesons mediate the strong force which keeps these nucleons bound to one another This requires less energy overall than when Mesons donâ€™t get created and quarks have nowhere to go. In this manner, the quarks and gluons are stable with less energy, and therefore, the nucleons are stable. But if we look into the Hydrogen atom, we can only see a single nucleon there, i.e., a proton. It has no other neighboring nucleon to exchange quarks with. Therefore, the quarks and gluons that try to move out need much more energy to do so. Hence, the proton of Hydrogen would have more energy units in total than the proton of helium, which has its neighboring nucleons to exchange its quarks with at a lower expanse of energy.

This is the reason, why 4 atoms of Hydrogen weigh more than Helium when Helium itself is the sum of 4 atoms of hydrogen. This stability in the nucleons of Helium is mostly due to binding energy mediated by the strong force.

And this is the quantum mechanical explanation of why the sun releases so much energy. This energy from within helps the sun fight the battle for its survival against the collapsing gravitational force. This battle is, however, on behalf of us because itâ€™s the reason for life here on Earth.

But itâ€™s going to lose this battle eventually, when the nuclear fuel of the sun exhausts.

There was more to this topic of Stellar evolution. In fact, we didn't even start it the way I had planned earlier. It's just that while writing this blog, a lecture struck my mind that I had given at an institute. Therefore, I have some amazing memories with what I wrote today. It was the day when our physics teacher was absent, and I was given the chance to teach Solar energy. Instead of teaching them Solar energy (which is utilized on Earth), I taught them where the energy comes from, i.e., the nuclear physics of the sun. So I thought I'd explain it, well, here too. item.dc:creator: hiuazyeralygmailcom
item.content:encoded:
Understanding Hawking Radiation

Within the vastness of the universe, black holes remain mysterious and fascinating objects. Introduced in 1974 by the brilliant physicist Stephen Hawking, Hawking radiation is one of the most intriguing phenomena related to these cosmic behemoths.

Quantum Mechanics and Virtual Particles

The complex interplay of quantum mechanics is at the core of Hawking radiation. This basic hypothesis holds that space is not really empty, but rather teeming with virtual particles that appear and go in an instant. These virtual particles can materialize close to a black hole's event horizon, where one particle falls into the hole while its counterpart escapes into space.

Zero-Point Fluctuations and Vacuum Polarization

The nature of Hawking radiation is further clarified by the concept of vacuum fluctuations, which is explained by the Lamb shift phenomenon. These fluctuations cause subtle energy level shifts in particles such as electrons; this phenomenon has important ramifications for our comprehension of the quantum world.

Conspiracy of Black Hole Radiation

At first look, the idea that black holes release radiation could seem irrational. Hawking's hypothesis, however, offers a convincing answer. The feeble radiation seen from these celestial objects is caused by the possibility that when virtual particle pairs materialize close to the event horizon, one of the pairs may fall into the black hole and the other may escape. However, given the enormous distances and harsh conditions associated with black holes, finding these emissions remains a tough issue even with the theoretical foundations of Hawking radiation.

Conclusion

Originating from the combination of general relativity and quantum mechanics, this phenomenon provides an enticing look into the inner workings of the cosmos. We are faced with the sobering truth that our comprehension of the cosmos is simply a momentary glimpse of a reality far larger and more intricate than we can comprehend when we consider the mystery of black holes and the radiation they release.

Let us embrace the spirit of inquiry and curiosity in our quest to solve the riddles of the cosmos, as it is by these pursuits that we draw ever closerÂ to discovering the answers to the universe's mysteries.
